nodes.description: Dark matter that behaves like a thermal particle with mass less than 1 GeV.
nodes.title: wdm
nodes.label: Warm dark matter

nodes.description: Dark matter possessing a long-range self-interaction cross section.
nodes.title: sidm
nodes.label: Self-interacting dark matter

nodes.description: Dark matter composed of ultra-light scalar particles.
nodes.title: fuzzy
nodes.label: Fuzzy dark matter

nodes.description: Non-baryonic compact dark matter (i.e., primordial black holes)
nodes.title: macho
nodes.label: Massive compact dark matter

nodes.description: Very light dark matter in the form of axions or axion-like particles
nodes.title: alp
nodes.label: Axion-like dark matter

nodes.description: The satellite galaxy luminosity function is sensitive to the abundance of low-mass dark matter halos. LSST will be able to detect the faintest known satellites out to the virial radius of the Milky Way. In addition, it will be sensitive to the satellite populations of other nearby galaxies.
nodes.title: sat_lum_fn
nodes.label: Satellite luminosity function

nodes.description: Stellar streams from tidally disrupted star clusters and galaxies are extremely sensitive to gravitational perturbations. Gravitational interactions with dark matter subhalos can create gaps in stellar streams which could be detectable by LSST. LSST will detect and measure stellar streams at much larger radii.
nodes.title: stream_gaps
nodes.label: Gaps in stellar streams

nodes.description: Low mass dark matter halos in lensing galaxies can cause anamolous flux ratios in the images of multiply-lensed background sources. Through lense mass modeling, it may be possible to use these anomalies to probe dark matter substructures in the intervening lens. LSST will discover multiple strong lenses and will monitor them for time variability (variable background sources can also manifest as flux ratio anomalies).
nodes.title: flux_ratio
nodes.label: Strong lens flux ratio anomalies

nodes.description: The orbits of stellar streams are a precise tracer of the smooth gravitational field of the Milky Way. By modeling the orbits of streams it is possible to probe the density profile and triaxiality of the Milky Way dark matter halo.
nodes.title: stream_orbits
nodes.label: Stellar stream orbits

nodes.description: Lens mass modeling from strong lensing arcs can be used to probe the distribution of substructure in a small annulus around the Einstein radius of the lens. This can be used to statistically constrain the abundance of dark matter substructure. LSST will find strongly lensed arcs suitable for this study.
nodes.title: cluster_sl
nodes.label: Cluster strong lens model

nodes.description: Weak lensing can be used to measure the density profile and triaxiality of dark matter halos galaxy clusters and groups. LSST will produce a large area, high quality weak lensing shear map as well as a catalog of galaxy clusters.
nodes.title: cluster_wl
nodes.label: Cluster weak lens modeling

nodes.description: Gravitational lensing from compact dark matter can cause an achromatic brightening and dimming of a background star. LSST will be able to measure the lightcurves of billions of stars over long time windows. The use of micorlensing parallax will increase the sensitivity to ultra-long duration events.
nodes.title: microlens
nodes.label: Stellar microlensing

nodes.description: Gravitational nanolensing could potentially probe subsolar mass dark matter halos.
nodes.title: nanolens
nodes.label: Stellar nanolensing

nodes.description: Anomalous cooling mechanisms would produce a measureable change in the luminosity function of white dwarf stars. LSST will be able to detect faint white dwarfs through color cuts and proper motions.
nodes.title: wdlf
nodes.label: White dwarf luminosity function

nodes.description: Anomalous cooling mechanisms would alter stellar evolution to decrease the time that stars spend in the red giant branch (RGB). LSST could measure the relative abudances of RGB stars and stars in other evolutionary phases in resolved stellar systems.
nodes.title: rgb
nodes.label: Red Giant Branch Populations

nodes.description: Wide-binary stars are very loosly bound systems, and hence the lifetime and abundance of these systems is sensitive to the abundance of massive compact perturbers. Will LSST should be able to find candidate wide-binaries through color magnitude cuts?
nodes.title: wide_binary
nodes.label: Population of wide-binary stars

nodes.description: Colliding clusters offer an opportunity to measure offsets between the dark matter and visible centroids. Such offsets could result from self-interacting dark matter. LSST will find tens of thousands of clusters and could significantly increase the statistical. Measurements may be possible with LSST weak lensing, but it is likely that devoted optical and X-ray followup will be necessary.
nodes.title: cluster_centroid
nodes.label: Cluster centroid offsets

nodes.description: The splashback radius of galaxy clusters is a probe of dark matter halo density profiles.
nodes.title: splashback
nodes.label: Cluster splashback radius

nodes.description: By finding z > 2 quasars and close quasar pairs, LSST can help test small scale structure of dark matter in the high-redshift universe.
nodes.title: lyman_alpha
nodes.label: High-z quasars

nodes.description: LSST proper motions should allow for the measurement of local stellar kinematics and the local distribution of dark matter. This is an important normalization for direct detection dark matter experiments.
nodes.title: local_kinematics
nodes.label: Local stellar kinematics

nodes.description: LSST will find distant tracers (RR Lyrae, BHB stars, satellite clusters/galaxies, etc.) that will probe the Milky Way dark matter halo at large radius. This will help constrain the halo profile and triaxiality.
nodes.title: halo_kinematics
nodes.label: Halo stellar kinematics

nodes.description: LSST can search for anomalous magnification of supernova via gravitational lensing.  This can be used to test microlensing from compact dark matter and caustics from fuzzy dark matter .
nodes.title: sn_lensing
nodes.label: Supernova lensing

nodes.description: Ultra-diffuse galaxies are underluminous for their measured dark matter mass. Their formation may stress stellar-mass-halo-mass relationships. LSST will greatly increase our sensitivity to these galaxies.
nodes.title: udgs
nodes.label: Ultra-diffuse galaxies

nodes.description: Studies of very rare or extreme stars. Studies of individual stars may require large followup campaigns. For example: wide-binaries
nodes.title: istars
nodes.label: Individual stars

nodes.description: Studies of populations of stars. For example: Milky Way halo dynamics, stellar stream orbits.
nodes.title: pstars
nodes.label: Population of stars

nodes.description: Studies of very rare or extreme galaxies. Individual galaxy studies may require large followup campaigns. For example: the Dragonfly 44 ultra-diffuse galaxy
nodes.title: igalaxies
nodes.label: Individual galaxies

nodes.description: Studies of populations of galaxies. For example: satellite galaxy luminosity function, galaxy-shear correlations.
nodes.title: pgalaxies
nodes.label: Population of galaxies

nodes.description: Studies of very rare or extreme galaxy clusters. For example: the Bullet cluster.
nodes.title: iclusters
nodes.label: Individual clusters

nodes.description: Studies of populations of galaxy clusters. For example: statistical measurements of the splash back radius.
nodes.title: pclusters
nodes.label: Population of clusters

nodes.description: Studies of very rare or extreme transient sources. For example: cluster microlensing.
nodes.title: itransients
nodes.label: Individual transients

nodes.description: Studies of populations of transient sources. For example: supernova constraints on primordial black holes.
nodes.title: ptransients
nodes.label: Population of transients

categories.title: models
categories.description: A "model" is a theoretical framework describing the physical mechanism governing the microphysics of dark matter.  Examples: warm dark matter, axion dark matter, primordial black hole dark matter, etc.
categories.label: Models

categories.title: probes
categories.description: A "probe" is a physical prediction of how a model would produce an observable change in the universe that is distinguishable from the "standard" cold, collisionless LCDM. Examples: minimum subhalo mass, anomalous energy loss mechanism, halo triaxiliaty, etc.
categories.label: Probes

categories.title: measurements
categories.description: A "measurement" is a physical observable that can be measured to test a probe.  Examples: satellite galaxy luminosity function, galaxy-galaxy strong lensing flux anomalies, etc.
categories.label: Measurements

categories.title: targets
categories.description: A "target" is an astrophysical source or source class which is used to make a measurement.  Examples: populations of stars, individual galaxy clusters
categories.label: Targets
